SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue and lightheadedness.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional bloating. These symptoms have been present for approximately five weeks. The patient has been adhering to his medications and monitoring his blood pressure at home. He reports some difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to recent home renovations.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue and lightheadedness.
• Gastrointestinal: Occasional bloating.
• Respiratory: Shortness of breath with exertion, slight cough.
• Cardiovascular: Slight chest cramps.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Constitutional: Alert and oriented.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Cardiovascular: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Reduced pumping function at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam and chest X-ray findings.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and call if weight gain or shortness of breath occurs.
   • Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg a day.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today with right knee pain. The patient reports that she was changing a light bulb on a ladder when she stumbled and twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. This happened yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it has not provided significant relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation, currently on digoxin.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right knee pain and tenderness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.

Results:

X-ray of the right knee, ordered and obtained in the office today, shows no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present, but overall alignment is proper.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today with right knee pain after a fall.

Acute medial meniscus strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports twisting her knee during a fall, and physical examination reveals tenderness over the medial meniscus area.
• Additional Testing: If the pain does not improve in one week, we will obtain an MRI for further evaluation.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. Prescribe Motrin 800 mg every six hours with food for two weeks.

Atrial fibrillation.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is currently on digoxin for atrial fibrillation management.
• Medical Treatment: Continue digoxin as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up in 1 week.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. The patient reports that he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, causing a pop in his lower back. The pain has been persistent since the incident on Saturday. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat, but these have not provided significant relief. He reports some tingling in his toes on his right foot until Sunday afternoon, but this has since resolved.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss. Endorses back pain.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies cough or shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, or abdominal pain.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain and occasional knee pain.
• Neurological: Denies headache, dizziness, or syncope. Endorses tingling in toes (resolved).

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of lumbar spine, pain with flexion and extension of the back, negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
Back x-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Back pain: Lumbar strain from lifting.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Continue to ice the area, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2: Elevated hemoglobin A1c.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily.
   • Follow-up: Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

3. Hypertension: Elevated blood pressure readings.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis: Patient is managing knee pain well.
   • No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Annual exam, depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HPI:

Mr. Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy, who presents for his annual exam. He reports a tough spring due to pollen and moving his daughter to college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and has not had any incidents recently. He has been struggling with hypertension and is taking Norvasc, but sometimes forgets to take it on weekends. He experiences shortness of breath during exertion, especially when running in humid conditions.

EXAM:

Vital signs: Blood pressure 120/80.
Physical exam: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, lungs clear, no lower extremity edema, pain to palpation of sinuses.
EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT:

1. Depression - well-managed with Prozac 20 mg daily.
2. Hypertension - controlled with Norvasc, patient to continue current medication.
3. Prior lobectomy - no further follow-up needed with surgeon, patient exercising regularly and breathing function is fine.
4. Systolic ejection murmur - order echocardiogram for further evaluation.

PLAN:

1. Continue Prozac 20 mg daily, refill prescription.
2. Continue Norvasc for hypertension management, encourage patient to take medication consistently.
3. No further follow-up needed for prior lobectomy.
4. Order echocardiogram for evaluation of systolic ejection murmur.
5. Order routine blood work.
6. Follow up with patient through the patient portal regarding test results.

The nurse will be in to finalize the appointment.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents for right index finger pain. The patient was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her finger got caught on a strap and bent backward. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried applying ice and taking ibuprofen for the pain, but it has not improved significantly. The pain is worse with movement.

The patient also reports a history of constipation, for which she takes Miralax. She had an appendectomy at the age of 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Right Index Finger:
• Tenderness over the distal phalanx and joint
• No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint
• Pain with flexion

X-RAY

The x-ray of the right index finger shows no fractures and normal alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 48-year-old female presenting with right index finger pain after a skiing incident. Based on the physical examination and x-ray findings, the diagnosis is a right index finger contusion at the tip of the finger.

Treatment Plan:
• Aluminum foam splint for the right index finger
• Ibuprofen 600 mg every six hours for one week

The patient is advised to follow up if the pain does not improve within a week. The patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female who presents with a long-standing history of iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. She has been experiencing fatigue, shortness of breath, wheezing, headaches, chills, and increased sensitivity to cold. She also reports worsening anxiety and depression. The patient has been anemic since she was 13 years old and had a hysterectomy in 1996. She had a colonoscopy approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg tablets twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12 supplements.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

General: The patient is alert and oriented.
Cardiovascular: Heart sounds are normal.
Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is soft and non-tender.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia. She is currently taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12 supplements. The plan is to continue her current medications and have her take her iron pills with orange juice to improve absorption. She will be scheduled for an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If these tests are inconclusive, a capsule endoscopy will be considered. A referral to a hematologist has been made. The patient will be re-evaluated in 8-12 weeks with a CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate tests.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HPI:

Mr. Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches. His past clinical history is unremarkable. He was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention after a pituitary lesion was discovered during workup for headaches. The patient reports headaches located behind his eyes, with a dull nagging ache, gradually worsening over time. He denies any other symptoms such as fever, rashes, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

None

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Unremarkable

EXAM:

The patient is alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS:

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

IMPRESSION:

Pituitary adenoma with optic chiasmal compression.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa. The patient will be scheduled for surgery and will undergo a visual field test prior to surgery. He will also be referred to an eye doctor for a full exam. The patient is advised to call if he has any questions or concerns.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents as a new patient with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She reports having chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. The patient denies any recent episodes of chest pain. She experienced difficulty swallowing during the initial episode, which has also resolved. The patient mentions going through a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain. She denies any family history of GI problems.

ER records indicate normal cardiac workup, including EKG and blood tests.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Examination of Abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No pain or tenderness in the lower abdomen.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female with a history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents with a referral for esophagitis following an episode of chest pain and difficulty swallowing in October 2020. Cardiac issues were ruled out in the ER. Possible etiologies include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety.

Given the patient's stressful job transition at the time of the episode, it is suspected that she may have experienced an anxiety attack, with possible contributions from musculoskeletal etiologies. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. An EGD was discussed but deferred due to the patient being asymptomatic for an extended period. The patient will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidneys due to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidneys. She is a twin, born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation, with a birth weight of 4 pounds, 8 ounces. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, gastroesophageal reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has also seen a gastroenterologist, allergist, neurologist, orthopedic specialist, ophthalmologist, and audiologist.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Patient is well-nourished and slightly fussy during the examination.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: No issues reported.
• Cardiovascular: No issues reported.
• Respiratory: No issues reported.
• Gastrointestinal: History of gastroesophageal reflux and feeding difficulties.
• Genitourinary: Normal wet diaper count (8-10 per day).
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Neurological: Developmental delays, currently in therapy.
• Eyes: Small appearing eyes.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy during the examination.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with a history of Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of her kidneys. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for patients with this syndrome.

• Medical Reasoning: We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today to evaluate for any congenital anomalies.
• Follow-up: If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location. If the ultrasound is normal, no further follow-up with nephrology will be needed.

End of the clinical note.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right wrist pain and swelling. The onset of her pain began yesterday morning after slipping on the stairs while doing laundry. She tried to catch herself and put her arms out, resulting in immediate pain and swelling in her right wrist. The patient denies any previous injury to this arm. She rates the pain as 9 out of 10 in severity. She has tried icing, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen for pain, which provides partial relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right wrist pain and swelling. Neurological: Reports mild tingling in fingers.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 140/70 mmHg, Heart rate: 80 bpm, Respiratory rate: 20 breaths/min, Temperature: 97.2°F. All vital signs are within normal limits except for slightly elevated blood pressure and heart rate, likely due to pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the right wrist: Obvious swelling and ecchymosis. Tenderness on palpation throughout. Limited range of motion in all directions due to pain. Bony crepitus noted. Able to make a fist but not tightly. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right wrist were obtained and reviewed today. These reveal a Colles' fracture with extra-articular involvement and ulnar styloid fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Right wrist Colles' fracture.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with her regarding her current symptoms and treatment options. I have recommended surgery to repair the fracture and ensure proper healing. In the meantime, the patient will be provided with a brace for her right wrist. She will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management. Following surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for a course of treatment to strengthen her wrist and prevent future injury. The patient will follow up with me in one month to assess her progress and discuss her upcoming vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the surgery is completed and physical therapy has begun for further evaluation and discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Philip is a patient with a past medical history of hypertension who presents with right knee pain following a fall while working on his property. The patient reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced pain, swelling, and discomfort in the right knee for the past week. The pain is rated as 4/10 when moving and is mainly located on the medial aspect of the knee. The patient has been taking ibuprofen for swelling.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Respiratory
Lungs: Clear bilaterally, no wheezes or crackles.

Musculoskeletal
Right knee: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect, pain with flexion and extension, edema, and effusion.

RESULTS
Imaging

Right knee X-ray: No fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

• Right knee MCL strain.
• Hypertension.

PLAN

Right knee MCL strain
1. Prescribe ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day for pain and swelling.
2. Provide knee brace for support and healing.
3. Recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes, 3-4 times a day.
4. Advise elevation and rest for the affected leg.

Hypertension
1. Continue Lisinopril 20 mg.
2. Refer to nutritionist for dietary management.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow the prescribed treatment plan and schedule a follow-up appointment. Call the clinic with any additional concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a patient who presents today with left shoulder pain that has been ongoing for approximately three weeks. He is unsure of any specific injury but has been active and doing work in his basement. He has had some previous aches and pains in the shoulder but nothing that Tylenol couldn't manage. The pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours for pain relief, which helps but does not eliminate the pain.

PAST HISTORY

No significant past medical history.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Extra strength Tylenol.

ALLERGIES

No known allergies.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Left shoulder exam: Limited active and passive range of motion, tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.

Neurovascular exam of the left arm: Capillary refill less than three seconds, sensation intact to light touch.

X-RAY

Left shoulder X-ray: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

1. Order an MRI for the left shoulder to further evaluate the cause of the pain.
2. Refer the patient to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks.
3. Continue taking Tylenol for pain relief.
4. Consider a steroid injection for the shoulder if symptoms do not improve after physical therapy.
5. Schedule a follow-up visit after completing physical therapy.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will receive educational materials on physical therapy and what to expect. He will schedule a follow-up visit after completing physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain and instability.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a patient with a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes who presents today with left knee pain and instability. The patient reports that the knee occasionally gives out while walking, causing her to nearly fall. The pain is internal and involves the whole kneecap. The patient denies any history of injury to the knee and has not taken any pain medication, as the pain does not last long. The patient is concerned about an upcoming trip that involves walking and line dancing, and she is hesitant to participate due to her knee issues.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No chest pain or shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left knee pain and instability.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
• Pulmonary: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

Results:

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain and instability.
   • Medical Reasoning: Arthritis is suspected due to the patient's description of pain and instability.
   • Medical Treatment: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily.
   • Specialist Referrals: Consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.

2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient has been compliant with medications and monitoring blood pressure at home.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.

3. Diabetes mellitus type 2.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient has been compliant with metformin and monitoring blood sugar levels.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed.
   • Additional Testing: Order hemoglobin A1c and lipid panel to assess diabetes control and potential adjustments to medication.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed and will be scheduled for an echocardiogram.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy for stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer who presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time.

The patient reports minimal cough and sore throat today. She has experienced some fatigue but no nausea or vomiting. The cough is described as a light, dry cough without shortness of breath. The sore throat is persistent, and the patient has been drinking fluids to alleviate the discomfort. She has not experienced any difficulty swallowing or feeling of food getting stuck.

The patient feels supported by the nursing staff and her family members during her treatment journey.

PAST HISTORY

Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, oxygen levels within normal range.
Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation.
Lower extremities: No edema.

ASSESSMENT

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
2. Mild radiation pneumonitis.
3. Painful swallowing.

PLAN

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer:
   - Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide).
   - Continue current dose of radiation at 45 Gy.
   - Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Mild radiation pneumonitis:
   - Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation.

3. Painful swallowing:
   - Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (four times a day) to alleviate pain and facilitate eating and drinking.

INSTRUCTIONS

Take prescribed medications as directed. Call clinic with any additional concerns or worsening symptoms. Schedule a follow-up appointment after completion of radiation treatment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal lab work - low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a middle-aged adult who was referred by their primary care physician due to a low immunoglobulin A level found during a recent physical examination. The patient reports a history of frequent colds that tend to linger but is unsure if this is more than usual. The patient denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. The patient has a family history of type 2 diabetes and was recently started on metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: No fever, weight loss, or weight gain.
• Respiratory: Reports frequent colds that linger.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal infections or diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital signs: Stable and within normal limits.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender, no organomegaly.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without complications. The patient does not report frequent infections that are difficult to control.
   • Additional Testing: Order blood work to check other antibody levels.
   • Patient Education: Instruct the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a family history of diabetes and was recently started on metformin.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed by the primary care physician.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after the additional blood work is completed. The patient is advised to watch for any infections that do not resolve or are difficult to control and to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents with right elbow pain for the past four days. He reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic, which he believes may have contributed to the pain. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and can radiate down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right elbow pain and discomfort in the forearm.
• All other systems reviewed and are negative.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation at the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Vitals are within normal limits.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality detected.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Medial epicondylitis (right elbow pain).
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms, physical examination findings, and recent increase in pottery activities are consistent with medial epicondylitis.
• Medical Treatment: The patient is advised to rest the affected arm, wear a sling while awake, apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg q.6 h. with food for a full week. He is also advised to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.
• Follow-up: The patient will be seen in one week for re-evaluation of his elbow pain.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient with a history of hypertension who presents with chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports falling outside and experiencing chest pain, which he initially dismissed as heartburn. He was recently in the emergency department where he was found to have swollen ankles and elevated blood pressure (200/90). The patient admits to missing his medications occasionally and not adhering to a proper diet, consuming salty foods like chips.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, nausea, or vomiting.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Blood Pressure: 128/72 in the office today.
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable from previous exam.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.
• Extremities: Trace edema in lower extremities.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Elevated.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram from ER visit: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

David is a patient with a history of hypertension presenting with chest pain and shortness of breath.

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily.
• Additional Testing: Renal artery ultrasound.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Consult with nutritionist, weigh daily, and call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient has been inconsistent with medication use and has not been adhering to a proper diet.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage consistent medication use, obtain a blood pressure cuff for home monitoring, and follow up with nutritionist for dietary guidance.

Smoking cessation.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient reports occasional smoking.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage continued efforts to quit smoking.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sharp pain in the right side of the abdomen below the ribs for the last several days.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with a sharp pain in the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain comes and goes, and when it comes, it is severe. He experiences burning sensation during urination and his urine appears darker than usual. He has taken Tylenol for the pain, but it has not been helpful. He feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones and has had them before but was able to pass them.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Kidney stones.

FAMILY HISTORY

Father had kidney stones.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdominal exam: No tenderness to palpation, no evidence of rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter, no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage the patient to push fluids to facilitate urination and help pass the stone.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, continue alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a strainer for the patient to strain urine and collect the stone for testing.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess progress and discuss further treatment options if necessary, such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy.
6. Instruct the patient to contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

INSTRUCTIONS

Push fluids, take prescribed medications, use the strainer to collect the stone, and call the clinic with any questions or worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a patient with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a non-healing foot ulcer on his right foot. He first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The ulcer began as a blister, which later became unroofed with thick, soft, and mushy skin underneath. The patient reports a foul smell and yellow drainage from the wound. He has been on antibiotics for six days, prescribed by his primary care provider. The patient has experienced fever, chills, and a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle. The area around the wound has turned black, and the patient reports cramping in his calf muscle. He has also experienced coughing and shortness of breath in the past two days.

The patient's blood sugar has been trending higher in the past few weeks, with some readings in the 300-400 range and one spike at 500-600. His A1C is 6.7, and he has been well-controlled for the past two years.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, and erythema. No bony exposure. No palpable dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses.

RESULTS

Right Foot X-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT

• Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer
• Elevated blood sugars
• Possible cellulitis

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture of the wound and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's calf closely.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
6. Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain good blood sugar control.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue the current antibiotic therapy as prescribed by the primary care provider. Await culture results and adjust antibiotic therapy as needed. Follow up with endocrinologist for diabetes management. Return to the clinic in 7 days for a follow-up appointment.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a patient who presents today with a tick bite on his right knee. He is unsure where he got the tick bite but spends time outdoors and went hunting a couple of weeks ago. The tick bite has been present for over a week and is causing burning and discomfort. The patient denies fever, chills, joint pain, difficulty moving the knee, or problems walking. He has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease. Since the tick bite, he has experienced headaches and generally not feeling well but denies any flu-like symptoms, cough, shortness of breath, or dizziness.

The patient also has a history of hypertension and diabetes. He has been taking lisinopril and metformin as prescribed and checking his blood pressure and blood sugars periodically. He reports his blood sugars have been running in the 120s.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: BP 122/70, HR 67, Temp 98.4°F

Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmur, rub, or gallop.

Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

Right Knee: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance over the right patella, pain to palpation, full range of motion.

Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes.

PLAN

1. Tick bite with possible Lyme disease.
   - Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks.
   - Order Lyme titer and Western blot.
   - Monitor for response to treatment and potential need for IV antibiotics.

2. Hypertension.
   - Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day.
   - Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
   - Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.
   - Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control.
   - Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

- Take medications as prescribed.
- Monitor blood pressure and blood sugars regularly.
- Follow up for test results and further evaluation.
- Call with any questions or concerns.
